awd_titl_txt: Developing the Environmental Literacy Concept Inventory
awd_abstract_narration:
Living things, from bacteria to humans, are all affected by their environment, and changes in this environment can have unexpected consequences, both positive and negative.  Faculty report having difficulty teaching how environmental changes can affect living things, often because students do not understand how such changes intersect with their own lives.  Education about interactions between the environment and living systems has the potential to help students relate environmental change to their own lives and foster an environmentally literate STEM workforce.  However, these education efforts are limited because no tool currently exists to measure student knowledge of environmental impacts on living things.  To improve the effectiveness of instruction in environmental literacy, biology educators need a valid and reliable way to measure student understanding in this area.  Concept inventories are sets of multiple choice questions that evaluate students' conceptual knowledge about a topic and help to measure how much students understand about it.  These inventories can identify what aspects of a topic are difficult for students, and track student learning over time.  Concept inventories can also be used to test the effectiveness of various teaching strategies.  This project will develop and test a concept inventory focused on environmental literacy in biology, with the overall goal of enhancing undergraduate environmental education.

The purpose of the environmental literacy concept inventory is to provide educators with a tool to measure student understanding of environmental impacts on biotic systems.  The project will conduct a qualitative study and collect interview data to identify undergraduate student and faculty understanding of the biological impacts of environmental change.  This information will be used to create an environmental literacy concept inventory.  The project will use the inventory with a sample of students in biology classes across the country and then use those results to improve the inventory.  The project will then conduct a pre- and post-test quantitative study using the revised inventory to identify students' knowledge of environmental impacts on biotic systems.  Project activities are aimed at developing a valid and reliable assessment tool, as well as producing research data on students' understanding of environmental impacts on biotic systems.  The inventory and data will guide faculty efforts to improve undergraduate students' environmental literacy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Living things rely on, yet also contend with, changes to their environment. Ecological principles help scientists generally predict how organisms respond to disturbances; however, climate change is a disturbance with unique spatial patterning and temporal effects. Students, even at the undergraduate level, still struggle to understand how climate change affects biotic systems, and faculty report challenges with teaching about climate change impacts on biotic systems. Further, educational efforts have been limited by the previous lack of a valid and reliable classroom assessment inventory to measure students' understanding of the impacts of climate change on living things and their environment. The central goal of this project was to develop such an instrument.


We followed a four-stage development process. The first stage, to determine the content of our novel inventory, proved the most challenging. Minimal research had described undergraduate student conceptions about climate change, much less their understanding of how this unique disturbance impacts living things. Through a multi-phase interview study, we describe that undergraduate biology students have many accurate ideas about how climate change might affect animals. However, some of their ideas related to evolution and the tolerance of some animals to different climates did not align with ideas accepted by science. Results of this inquiry led to development of the educational framework, the Biotic Impacts of Climate Change Core Concepts or BIC4, which outlines key concepts related to understanding how living things will be impacted by climate change. We believe this framework will support educators as they create curriculum and researchers as they assess student understanding. During the second stage, we leveraged these previous studies to develop an initial set of questions or items for our inventory. These items focused on the Species-level or System-level Outcomes of climate change, as well as the Scale of Outcomes.


Following a series of revisions involving interviewing and surveying undergraduate and graduate students as well as instructors and experts in the fields of biology and ecology, we conducted a series of two field tests (i.e. the third and fourth phases of the development process). Soliciting participation from a diverse set of undergraduate students in advanced ecology and introductory biology classes, we completed two instrument development cycles of data collection, analysis, and modification to create a finalized conceptual inventory. The final data set used for analysis included 859 students from 20 institutions. This new instrument, called the Inventory of Biotic Climate Literacy (IBCL), includes 30 items, representing 16 measured constructs. Designed for use with undergraduate students, the ICBL measures students' knowledge of climate change impacts on biotic systems.


We anticipate that this inventory will be used to describe stronger or weaker areas of students? understanding of the impacts of climate change on living things. The inventory was developed using introductory biology and advanced ecology students from 15 US states to increase the breadth of undergraduate populations with whom this inventory might be used. We expect that the IBCL will be successful at detecting the impact of curricular interventions (e.g. class activities, assignments) focused on this topic.


To date, this project has produced two peer-reviewed publications, with further papers in preparation and under review. The final inventory will be available through a forthcoming publication. Several graduate and undergraduate students and a postdoc were trained in qualitative data collection and analysis, content analysis, and classical test theory metrics.
